# Terrorist Organizations Since the Cold War and Their Links to Iran

## Islamic State (ISIS)
**Origins and Ideology:** The Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS), also known as ISIL or Daesh, arose from the remnants of **al-Qaeda in Iraq (AQI)** – a jihadist group formed by Abu Musab al-Zarqawi in 2004 during the Iraqi insurgency【33†L223-L231】. After being weakened by Iraq’s Sunni tribal awakening and U.S. troop surge (2007–2008), the group rebranded as the **Islamic State of Iraq** and later exploited the chaos of the Syrian Civil War to reconstitute itself【33†L223-L231】. In 2013 it expanded to Syria and adopted the name ISIS【33†L230-L238】. ISIS’s ideology is violently **Salafi-jihadist**, aiming to establish a puritanical Sunni caliphate. It is notorious for extreme sectarianism – viewing Shia Muslims (and other minorities) as apostates – and for its brutality (e.g. grotesque beheadings and massacres) used as propaganda and intimidation【36†L450-L458】. In June 2014, ISIS captured Mosul and Tikrit, after which leader **Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi** declared a **“Caliphate”** spanning parts of Syria and Iraq【33†L230-L238】.

**Major Activities and Timeline:** At its zenith (2014–2015), ISIS ruled over large swaths of eastern Syria and northern Iraq, imposing its harsh interpretation of Islamic law. It perpetrated genocide against Iraq’s Yazidi minority and enslaved thousands, and orchestrated or inspired terror attacks across the globe. In 2015, the group spawned affiliates in **Libya, Egypt (Sinai), Nigeria (Boko Haram pledged allegiance), Afghanistan (ISIS-K),** and elsewhere. High-profile attacks claimed by ISIS included the bombings in **Beirut (2015)**, downing of a Russian airliner over Sinai (2015), and coordinated massacres in **Paris (Nov 2015)** and **Brussels (2016)**. A U.S.-led global coalition, together with local Kurdish, Iraqi, and Syrian forces (and also Iran-backed militias on the ground), steadily rolled back ISIS’s territory. By December 2017, ISIS had lost 95% of its former territory – including its capital Raqqa and Iraq’s second city, Mosul【33†L223-L231】【33†L234-L242】. Baghdadi was killed in a 2019 U.S. raid, and ISIS morphed back into an underground insurgency. Despite its territorial defeat, ISIS remains active through sleeper cells in the Middle East and franchises in Africa and South Asia.

**Links to Iran:** **Iran, a Shia power, was fiercely opposed to ISIS**, a Sunni extremist movement that expressly targeted Shia communities. There is **no credible evidence of Iranian financial or logistical support to ISIS**; on the contrary, Iran actively fought ISIS. When ISIS blitzed across Iraq in 2014, Iran’s Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) mobilized Shia militias to defend Baghdad and Shia holy cities【2†L55-L63】. Iranian commanders (like IRGC–Quds Force General Qassem Soleimani) helped Iraqi forces and militias retake territory from ISIS【2†L59-L67】. In Syria, Iran (and its proxy **Hezbollah**) likewise intervened to prop up the Assad regime against ISIS and other rebels. U.S. defense officials have noted Iran’s *ambiguous* stance – Iran opposed ISIS, yet sought to leverage the ISIS threat to expand its own influence. Notably, a 2009 U.S. intelligence report cited Iran’s “**ambiguous role**,” providing support to the new Iraqi government while **allowing weapons to reach the Taliban** (a separate Sunni insurgency) – a sign of Iran’s complex regional strategy【29†L115-L123】. With ISIS, however, Iran’s role was unambiguous: Tehran openly denounced ISIS as a **terrorist threat** and welcomed its defeat. Some regional adversaries (e.g. Saudi Arabia) alleged that the Iran-allied Assad regime deliberately spared ISIS early on to weaken other rebels, but such claims remain unproven. In sum, **no direct Iran–ISIS cooperation** is documented; rather, Iran’s IRGC and its proxies fought ISIS on the battlefield. Iranian officials frequently pointed to this fact to claim credit for fighting “Sunni extremism,” even as the U.S. and others criticized Iran for simultaneously backing Shia militias that exacerbated sectarian tensions in Iraq【2†L61-L69】. Iran’s strategy thus treated ISIS as an enemy, not an asset, and Iranian leaders continue to celebrate the collapse of ISIS’s caliphate as a joint victory for Iran and its allies in the region.

*(Sources: Wilson Center, Council on Foreign Relations, Brookings Institution, congressional testimony【33†L223-L231】【33†L230-L238】【36†L450-L458】【2†L55-L63】)*

## Al-Qaeda
**Origins and Ideological Underpinnings:** **Al-Qaeda** was formed in the late 1980s in the wake of the anti-Soviet jihad in Afghanistan. **Osama bin Laden** and a cadre of Arab volunteer fighters, emboldened by the Soviet withdrawal, founded al-Qaeda in 1988 as an elite vanguard to **globalize jihad**【36†L408-L417】. Bin Laden’s vision was to unite disparate Islamist militant groups under one umbrella and turn their focus toward the “far enemy” – particularly the United States – which he blamed for propping up corrupt regimes in Muslim lands【36†L408-L416】. Throughout the 1990s, under Bin Laden and his deputy **Ayman al-Zawahiri**, al-Qaeda developed a Salafi-jihadist ideology advocating violent jihad against both “near enemies” (local governments) and “far enemies” (the U.S. and Israel) in defense of the Muslim ummah. Al-Qaeda’s ideology is Sunni extremist, but notably **anti-Shia** as well – although al-Qaeda often downplayed sectarian rhetoric relative to ISIS. Bin Laden saw the Shia Iranian regime as infidels, yet he was pragmatic in choosing enemies and allies.

**Major Activities:** Al-Qaeda announced itself on the world stage with spectacular anti-American attacks. It was responsible for the August 1998 bombings of the U.S. embassies in **Kenya and Tanzania** (killing 224) and the October 2000 attack on the **USS Cole** in Yemen【36†L422-L430】. On September 11, 2001, al-Qaeda carried out the deadliest terrorist attacks in history on U.S. soil, hijacking airliners to strike New York’s World Trade Center and the Pentagon, killing ~3,000 people. The 9/11 attacks made al-Qaeda a household name and provoked the U.S.-led “War on Terror”【36†L422-L430】. The U.S. invasion of Afghanistan in late 2001 toppled al-Qaeda’s Taliban hosts and killed or captured many al-Qaeda members. Bin Laden evaded capture until May 2011, when U.S. Navy SEALs killed him in Pakistan. In the years after 9/11, **al-Qaeda’s network expanded** through affiliates: **Al-Qaeda in Iraq** (which later broke away as ISIS), **Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP)** in Yemen, **Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (Northwest Africa)**, **Al-Shabaab** in Somalia (which pledged loyalty), and others. Al-Qaeda and its branches carried out numerous bombings, hostage-takings, and shootings across South Asia, the Middle East, and Africa. However, intense counterterrorism pressure severely degraded the core leadership. Zawahiri, who succeeded Bin Laden, was killed by a U.S. drone in Kabul in 2022, and al-Qaeda today operates more as a diffuse network of regional franchises.

**Links to Iran:** The relationship between **al-Qaeda and Iran** is **complicated and highly controversial**. On the surface, a hardline Sunni jihadist group and the revolutionary Shiite Islamic Republic are **ideological arch-foes**; indeed, al-Qaeda’s propaganda often condemned Shia Iran. Yet **evidence shows a pattern of tactical cooperation** dating back to the 1990s. According to the U.S. 9/11 Commission and declassified intelligence, **Sudan** (in the early 1990s) facilitated contacts between al-Qaeda and Iran’s IRGC and **Hezbollah**. **Imad Mughniyeh**, Hezbollah’s top operative, reportedly met Bin Laden in the mid-1990s, and Iran’s security forces allegedly provided *some training in explosives to al-Qaeda members* in Sudan and in Lebanon’s Bekaa Valley【15†L25-L34】【15†L37-L44】. The **9/11 Commission** found that Iran had “*facilitated the transit of al-Qaeda members into and out of Afghanistan before 9/11, and … some of these were future 9/11 hijackers*”【11†L158-L162】. Notably, Iranian border officials allowed several of the 9/11 hijackers to pass through Iran (from Afghanistan to Saudi Arabia) without stamping passports, presumably to conceal their travel to Afghanistan【11†L158-L164】. There is no evidence Iran had foreknowledge of 9/11, but it demonstrated a willingness to permit al-Qaeda operatives to use Iranian territory for transit. 

After 9/11, as the U.S. hunted al-Qaeda, **scores of al-Qaeda members fled into Iran**. In late 2001, Tehran **offered to open its border** to **“Arab volunteers”** heading to Afghanistan to fight U.S. forces【11†L160-L167】. By 2002-2003, **senior al-Qaeda leaders and family members** (including Osama bin Laden’s sons, Saif al-Adel – a top military chief, and Abdullah Ahmed Abdullah a.k.a. Abu Muhammad al-Masri) were detained or harbored in Iran【15†L49-L57】【15†L79-L87】. Iran’s regime portrayed this as “house arrest” of unwanted guests, and in 2003 it did **crack down** on al-Qaeda cells, deporting some fighters and restraining others【11†L177-L185】. However, many **key figures lived under a form of safe custody** in Iran for years – protected from U.S. capture, but also closely monitored by Iran. U.S. intelligence assessed that during the mid-2000s this Iran-based al-Qaeda network (sometimes dubbed the “**Al-Qaeda Management Council**”) was able to **reorganize and direct terrorist operations from Iranian soil**【11†L169-L175】. A **2015 hostage swap** confirmed the ongoing ties: Iran released several al-Qaeda leaders (including Saif al-Adel and Abu Muhammad al-Masri) in exchange for an Iranian diplomat held by al-Qaeda’s Yemen affiliate【15†L101-L109】. Some of those freed relocated to Syria; others, like al-Masri, *remained in Iran*. (Al-Masri was later **assassinated in Tehran in 2020**, reportedly by Israeli agents, underscoring Iran’s harboring of al-Qaeda’s top echelon【15†L125-L134】.)

In recent years, **Iran’s harboring of al-Qaeda’s leadership has continued**. After Zawahiri’s death in 2022, the **likely new emir, Saif al-Adel, is believed to be based in Iran** under the protection of the IRGC【15†L7-L15】. The UN and multiple governments have noted al-Adel’s continued presence in Iran as a critical issue for al-Qaeda’s future. U.S. officials (e.g. former Secretary of State Mike Pompeo) have characterized Iran as al-Qaeda’s “**new home base**” and a core facilitation hub【11†L117-L125】【50†L68-L74】. In 2021, the U.S. Treasury revealed that **al-Qaeda used Iran as a transit and logistics base** to move operatives and money across the Middle East and South Asia【50†L68-L74】. Iranian and Hezbollah operatives allegedly served as intermediaries for al-Qaeda in some regions【11†L139-L148】. 

Despite this **“**unlikely alliance**”**, both sides deny formal cooperation. Iranian officials insist they have only detained (or expelled) al-Qaeda members, not assisted them. Al-Qaeda’s leaders have been circumspect, not wanting to alienate Sunni supporters or admit reliance on Shiite Iran【15†L7-L15】. Analysts assess that Iran sees al-Qaeda as a **tool of convenience** – useful to harass U.S. forces in Afghanistan or Iraq, or to influence Sunni jihadist battlefields, but too dangerous to fully unleash. For al-Qaeda, refuge in Iran has been a **desperate lifeline** during times of U.S. pressure【11†L149-L157】. This **transactional relationship** is characterized by mutual mistrust: Iran reportedly imposed limits on al-Qaeda activities from its soil, while at times imprisoning or deporting members to gain leverage or goodwill (for example, briefly cooperating with the U.S. in 2003 by arresting some operatives【11†L177-L185】). Still, the **evidence of direct links is significant**: U.S. courts (e.g. the *Cabrera v. Iran* case) have ruled that Iran materially aided al-Qaeda by sheltering its leaders and facilitating travel【50†L75-L83】. In summary, **Iran’s ties to al-Qaeda have been opportunistic and opaque** – a marriage of convenience against common enemies (the U.S. and its allies), rather than a deep ideological alliance. Both Tehran and al-Qaeda’s Sunni extremists publicly downplay their collusion, yet over the past three decades Iran repeatedly provided *“critical life support”* to al-Qaeda when it suited Tehran’s interests【11†L149-L157】.

*(Sources: Brookings Institution, Lawfare, 9/11 Commission Report, FDD/Long War Journal investigations, U.S. Treasury and court documents【11†L158-L162】【15†L49-L57】【50†L59-L67】【50†L68-L74】)*

## Hezbollah 
**Formation and Ideology:** **Hezbollah** (Arabic for “Party of God”) is a Shiite Islamist militant group and political party based in Lebanon. It was formed during the Lebanese Civil War, notably **in 1982** in response to Israel’s invasion of Lebanon. A faction of Lebanese Shi’a militants, influenced and aided by Iran’s newly-established Islamic Revolutionary government, coalesced to form Hezbollah【21†L328-L337】. Iran’s **Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC)** deployed to Lebanon’s Bekaa Valley in the early 1980s to train and arm these militants; with Iranian funding and guidance, the *“budding militia”* adopted the name Hezbollah【21†L328-L336】. Hezbollah’s 1985 manifesto explicitly **pledged allegiance to Iran’s Supreme Leader** and embraced the doctrine of Iran’s Ayatollah Khomeini (wilayat al-faqih, or guardianship of the Islamic jurist)【21†L339-L347】. The group’s core ideology is staunchly **anti-Israel and anti-Western**. Hezbollah presents itself as a “resistance” movement defending Lebanon and the Muslim world from Israeli aggression and Western imperialism. It also harbors the long-term goal of establishing an Islamic order in Lebanon, though it pragmatically operates within Lebanon’s multi-sectarian political system. Importantly, Hezbollah is **Iran’s closest proxy**: it subscribes to Shia Islamist ideology and views Iran’s Supreme Leader as its ultimate religious authority【21†L341-L347】. This ideological alignment has underpinned a tight relationship wherein Iran provides patronage and Hezbollah furthers Iran’s regional agenda.

**Key Figures and Structure:** Hezbollah’s early leaders included **Sheikh Subhi al-Tufayli** and **Abbas al-Musawi**, but since 1992 it has been led by **Hassan Nasrallah** – under whose leadership Hezbollah grew into a formidable force. Nasrallah (killed in 2024 per recent reports【17†L229-L237】) became the charismatic face of Hezbollah, helping transform it from a shadowy militia into a powerful quasi-state entity. The organization has a political wing (which holds seats in Lebanon’s parliament and cabinet) and a military wing (the **Islamic Resistance**). It also runs extensive social services, schools, and media – making it a “state within a state” in Shiite areas of Lebanon【17†L268-L277】. 

**Major Activities and Timeline:** During the 1980s, Hezbollah earned infamy for attacks on Western targets in Lebanon, allegedly with Iranian direction. **In 1983**, Hezbollah operatives (with IRGC support) carried out suicide truck bombings against the U.S. Marine barracks and French paratrooper barracks in Beirut, killing 299 U.S. and French personnel【21†L331-L338】. Hezbollah (or its predecessor cells like Islamic Jihad Organization) was also blamed for the 1984 U.S. Embassy annex bombing in Beirut and the kidnapping of dozens of Western hostages in Lebanon in the 1980s. Throughout the 1990s, Hezbollah fought an insurgency against Israeli occupation in southern Lebanon, eventually *forcing Israel’s withdrawal in 2000*, which boosted Hezbollah’s prestige. Outside Lebanon, Hezbollah is accused of the 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center (AMIA) in Buenos Aires and the 1996 Khobar Towers bombing in Saudi Arabia (the latter targeting U.S. Air Force personnel), though it denies involvement. In **2006**, Hezbollah fought a **34-day war with Israel** after a cross-border raid. Hezbollah fired thousands of rockets into northern Israel while Israel bombarded Lebanon; the war ended inconclusively but at great cost to Lebanon’s infrastructure. In the 2010s, Hezbollah intervened heavily in **Syria’s civil war** on Iran’s behalf. Starting in 2012–2013, Hezbollah deployed thousands of fighters to Syria to prop up Bashar al-Assad’s regime, playing a crucial role (along with IRGC and Russia) in turning the tide against Syrian rebel forces【39†L512-L520】【39†L514-L523】. This expedition came at a price: Hezbollah took significant casualties and alienated many Sunnis (who opposed Assad), but it **gained battle-hardened experience** and new weaponry. By 2019, Hezbollah began partially withdrawing fighters from Syria after shoring up Assad【39†L514-L522】. Today, Hezbollah possesses an arsenal of an estimated 100,000+ rockets and missiles (supplied largely by Iran) threatening Israel, and has been entangled in periodic skirmishes with Israel even as it also faces criticism at home for dragging Lebanon into conflicts【39†L528-L537】【39†L538-L546】. Most recently, during the 2023 Israel–Hamas war, Hezbollah launched limited attacks on northern Israel “in solidarity” with Hamas, raising fears of a broader war orchestrated by Iran【39†L597-L605】.

**Direct Links to Iran:** Hezbollah is often cited as **“Revolutionary Iran’s most successful export”**, epitomizing Iran’s strategy of projecting power via proxy militias【16†L25-L32】. The evidence of Iran’s role in Hezbollah’s rise and operations is abundant and explicit. **Iran’s IRGC founded Hezbollah** – IRGC officers trained the first Hezbollah fighters in the Bekaa Valley in 1982–84, and **Iran provided funds, arms, and advisers** to the group from its inception【21†L328-L336】. Hezbollah’s own manifesto and leaders openly acknowledge ideological fealty to Iran. Over the decades, Iran has reportedly supplied Hezbollah with advanced weapons: everything from rifles and RPGs to long-range missiles and attack drones have been funneled via Syria. A U.S. State Department report estimated Iran gives Hezbollah **~$700 million annually** in financial support in recent years【31†L131-L139】, enabling its expansive armed network. Iranian military officers (from the IRGC–Quds Force) act as liaisons and consultants to Hezbollah; for example, IRGC General **HosseIN Dehghan** was among the early commanders aiding Hezbollah in the 1980s. Iran often uses Hezbollah to train or assist other militias (e.g. in Iraq and Yemen), effectively making Hezbollah a regional proxy handler on Tehran’s behalf【21†L331-L338】. Hezbollah in turn has acted as Iran’s arm: conducting the 1992 and 1994 bombings in Argentina (according to Argentine and Israeli intelligence) as retaliation against Israel, assassinating Syrian dissidents, and attempting attacks on Israeli targets abroad (Cyprus, Thailand, etc.) at Iran’s behest. During the Syrian war, Iran deployed Hezbollah as an expeditionary force to keep the Assad regime (Iran’s ally) in power【39†L507-L515】【39†L514-L522】. The **Hezbollah–Iran relationship is formalized** to an unusual degree: Hezbollah’s Shura Council consults with Iranian officials, and Iran’s Supreme Leader Khamenei sends a personal representative to Beirut. In exchange for Iran’s patronage, Hezbollah largely hews to Tehran’s strategic direction (though tactical disagreements have occurred). 

Iranian officials proudly tout Hezbollah as a **“resistance” partner**. Conversely, the U.S. and many governments consider Hezbollah *wholly reliant on Iran*. For instance, a 2020 U.S. military report stated: *“Hezbollah serves as Iran’s proxy, its most powerful terrorist partner”*【17†L225-L233】. Even within Lebanon, opponents accuse Hezbollah of “acting as Iran’s agent” rather than a purely Lebanese actor. Notably, Hezbollah’s weapons and logistics pipeline runs through Iran’s ally Syria; Tehran and Damascus facilitate massive arms transfers to Hezbollah【39†L502-L509】. United Nations reports have documented violations of the arms embargo on Hezbollah, tracing them to Iran. Hezbollah’s own leader Nasrallah repeatedly thanks Iran for enabling the group’s military strength, saying in 2016: *“I will not shy away from mentioning the support of the Islamic Republic of Iran in terms of weapons, funding and training”*. Iranian state media often refers to Hezbollah fighters killed in Syria as “martyrs” for the Islamic Revolution, underlining the ideological bond.

In terms of **command and control**, analysts describe Hezbollah as **“Iran’s forward arm”**. However, Hezbollah does maintain a degree of autonomy in Lebanese politics – it must balance its domestic standing with loyalty to Iran. There have been moments (such as internal Lebanese matters or brief engagement with domestic opponents) where Hezbollah’s decisions reflected local interests. But on issues of war and peace (especially vis-à-vis Israel), Hezbollah coordinates closely with Iran. For example, the timing and rules of engagement of Hezbollah’s actions against Israel often align with Tehran’s calculus (e.g. not provoking an all-out war unless Iran green-lights it). Western and Arab intelligence have implicated Iran and Hezbollah together in numerous covert operations, from bomb plots in Europe and Asia to training Iraqi Shia militias that attacked U.S. troops in Iraq in the 2000s.

In summary, **Hezbollah is incontrovertibly linked to Iran** – it is *the* paradigm of an Iranian proxy. Iran’s financial and military sponsorship, ideological mentorship, and strategic tasking of Hezbollah have been affirmed by **U.S. government reports, Lebanese officials, and even Hezbollah’s own statements**【21†L328-L336】【17†L225-L233】. While Hezbollah has evolved (now also a political party governing parts of Lebanon), **Iran’s role remains foundational**, ensuring Hezbollah stays equipped and aligned with Tehran’s regional objectives. Officially, Iran dismisses the term “proxy,” claiming Hezbollah is an independent “resistance movement”; but Tehran openly celebrates Hezbollah’s battlefield victories as its own. The **state-level sponsorship** here is direct: Iran is under U.S. and international sanctions precisely for arming and funding Hezbollah as a terrorist organization. The Iranian government, particularly the IRGC’s Quds Force, effectively *created, and continues to sustain, Hezbollah*【21†L328-L336】. Without Iran, Hezbollah would likely not exist in its current form, and certainly would not wield such outsized influence. This symbiosis is perhaps the clearest case of post-Cold War state-sponsored terrorism, with Iran and Hezbollah denying none of it – instead, they frame it as an alliance against Israel and Western “aggression.”

*(Sources: Council on Foreign Relations, CFR Backgrounder updated 2024【21†L328-L336】【21†L331-L338】; Hezbollah 1985 Open Letter; U.S. State Dept Country Reports on Terrorism; Washington Institute analyses; United Nations reports)*

## Boko Haram
**Historical Overview:** **Boko Haram** is an extremist Islamist sect (now a jihadist insurgent group) based in **Nigeria**. Its official name is *Jama’atu Ahlis Sunnah Lidda’awati wal-Jihad* (“People Committed to the Propagation of the Prophet’s Teachings and Jihad”), but it became known as “Boko Haram,” which in the local Hausa language means “Western education is forbidden.” The group was founded around **2002** in Maiduguri, northeast Nigeria, by a charismatic cleric **Mohammed Yusuf**. Boko Haram emerged in a milieu of poor governance, economic hardship, and religious tension in northern Nigeria. Yusuf preached against corruption and Western influence, advocating a strict **Salafi-Islamic way of life** and the imposition of Sharia law. Early on, the sect was relatively quietist, establishing a commune and school. However, **in July 2009 Nigerian security forces cracked down** on the group, killing Yusuf and hundreds of followers. After Yusuf’s death (in police custody), his deputy **Abubakar Shekau** assumed leadership and transformed Boko Haram into a highly violent insurgency.

**Major Activities and Evolution:** From 2010 onward, Boko Haram launched a campaign of bombings, mass shootings, and kidnappings, primarily in Nigeria’s northeast. It targeted police, military, government offices, schools, churches, and civilians—killing tens of thousands over a decade. Notorious incidents include the **August 2011 suicide bombing of the UN headquarters in Abuja**, the January 2012 coordinated attacks in Kano that killed almost 200, and the abduction of 276 schoolgirls from **Chibok** in April 2014, which sparked global outrage. By 2014, Boko Haram seized control of a swath of territory in Borno and adjoining states, declaring a **“Islamic caliphate”** in areas like Gwoza. In March 2015, Shekau **pledged allegiance to ISIS**, and Boko Haram began calling itself the Islamic State’s “West Africa Province” (ISWAP)【24†L31-L39】. This led to a split: in 2016 a faction broke away (led by Abu Musab al-Barnawi) with ISIS’s backing, becoming ISWAP, while Shekau’s faction continued independently (often still dubbed Boko Haram). Boko Haram became infamously brutal, employing suicide bombers (including young girls) in mosques and markets, and massacring entire villages. Regional military offensives by Nigeria, Chad, Cameroon, and Niger gradually pushed Boko Haram out of its strongholds by 2017, though at a heavy cost. Shekau proved elusive until May 2021, when he reportedly killed himself to avoid capture by the rival ISWAP faction. Since then, Boko Haram’s activity has waned, while ISWAP (the splinter aligned with ISIS) remains active around Lake Chad. The insurgency has created one of the world’s worst humanitarian crises, with over 2 million displaced.

**Links to Iran:** **Boko Haram’s roots and ideology are Salafi-jihadist and anti-Shiite**, and it arose in the context of Sunni militancy in Nigeria – thus **direct linkages to Iran (a Shia regime) are not evident.** Unlike groups in the Middle East, Boko Haram’s connections have been primarily with Sunni extremist networks (al-Qaeda and later ISIS) rather than Iran. Over the years, investigations have uncovered Boko Haram ties to **al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM)** and training exchanges with groups in Mali and Somalia, but **no credible funding or training from Iran**. In fact, Boko Haram’s rhetoric condemns Western influence and the secular Nigerian state, rather than focusing on sectarian issues (the group generally targeted Christians and Nigerian security forces; it **did not overtly attack Shia minorities in Nigeria** in its early years)【24†L47-L54】. Given Boko Haram’s vehemently Sunni fundamentalist outlook, **ideological alignment with Iran’s Shia revolutionary government is essentially absent**.

That said, there have been a few **murky incidents and allegations** that raised questions about Iran’s role in Nigeria’s militant scene – though these mostly involve **Nigerian Shia organizations or Iran’s covert units, not Boko Haram**. One oft-cited event was the 2010 arrest in Nigeria of an Iranian Quds Force operative shipping a container of weapons to Nigeria (in violation of UN sanctions). Those arms were allegedly intended for **Shia militants in Nigeria or Gambia**, not for Boko Haram. Another incident occurred in **May 2013**, when Nigeria’s Joint Task Force raided a residence in Kano owned by a Lebanese national and discovered a hidden arms cache (including rockets and landmines). Nigerian authorities announced they had uncovered a local **Hezbollah cell** and suggested **“Boko Haram Islamist militants have connections with the Lebanon-based Hezbollah”**【27†L59-L67】. The arrested Lebanese suspects confessed to Hezbollah training, and officials indicated the weapons were likely meant for attacking Israeli or Western interests in Nigeria【27†L93-L100】. However, security analysts noted that this Hezbollah cell appeared separate from Boko Haram’s operations – essentially, **two distinct forms of militancy co-existing in Nigeria** (one driven by transnational Shia networks, the other by local Sunni jihadism). The Nigerian military’s statement linking Boko Haram to Hezbollah was not backed by public evidence of joint operations; it may have been referencing anecdotally that **some Nigerian Muslims had interacted with both movements**. In fact, one **former Boko Haram fighter claimed** he had first been part of an “Islamic movement called ‘the Shia’ that sent members to Iran for training” before joining a Boko Haram cell【24†L49-L54】. This suggests a *personal* trajectory (a recruit moving from a pro-Iranian Shia movement to Boko Haram), rather than institutional collusion. 

Overall, **no reliable documentation indicates Iranian state support for Boko Haram**. U.S. State Department and UK reports on terrorism have not identified Iran as a financier or sponsor of Boko Haram. On the contrary, Boko Haram’s funding is believed to come from local criminal activities (bank robberies, extortion, kidnapping for ransom) and possibly donations from Gulf-based jihadist sympathizers – not Iran. Indeed, **Iran and Boko Haram stand on opposite sides of the Sunni–Shia divide**, and Boko Haram’s allegiance to ISIS (which is virulently anti-Iran and anti-Shia) further underscores the lack of alignment. During the period when Boko Haram was ascendant, **Iran’s focus in Africa** regarding militancy was more on supporting Shia movements such as the **Islamic Movement in Nigeria (IMN)** led by Sheikh Ibrahim Zakzaky, who openly espoused Khomeini’s ideology. In a way, the rise of Boko Haram (Sunni jihadism) and the growth of the IMN (Shia activism) represented rival influences in Nigeria. There have been deadly clashes **between Boko Haram and the Nigerian Shia community** on a few occasions, but Boko Haram mostly viewed the Nigerian secular government and Christians as its primary enemies, rather than engaging in sectarian war.

Iran’s official stance on Boko Haram has been one of condemnation. Tehran has **publicly condemned Boko Haram’s terrorism**, especially its abduction of schoolgirls and attacks on Muslims and Christians. Iran has attempted to build relations with the Nigerian government and would have little to gain by empowering a Sunni extremist rebellion that destabilizes an oil-rich African state. Nigerian authorities, for their part, have been cautious not to frame Boko Haram’s insurgency in Sunni-Shia terms, focusing instead on its domestic roots. 

In summary, **Boko Haram and Iran have no known direct relationship**. The **only tangential links** have been: (1) Iranian intelligence operations in Nigeria targeting different foes (Israel/West or supporting Nigerian Shias), which briefly overlapped geographically with Boko Haram’s theater; and (2) a few Nigerians switching from Iranian-backed groups to Boko Haram, indicating complex personal ties in Nigeria’s religious landscape【24†L49-L54】. But **no evidence** suggests Iran funded, trained, or armed Boko Haram. Indeed, Boko Haram’s later alignment with ISIS placed it firmly in an anti-Iran camp. Multiple governments – including Nigeria’s and its neighbors – have **accused Boko Haram of many horrors, but not of being an Iranian proxy**. Accusations of state sponsorship have instead focused on other sources (e.g. some have speculated support from wealthy individuals in Gulf states). Iran’s proxy strategy in the Muslim world largely centers on empowering Shia or co-sectarian actors; Boko Haram does not fit that mold. Thus, on the question of Iranian linkages: **the evidence is essentially negative – a confirmation that Boko Haram’s rise was indigenous and Sunni-driven, without Iranian hand**.

## The Taliban
**Formation and Rule (1994–2001):** The **Taliban** are an Islamist movement that originated in southern **Afghanistan**. They arose in 1994 amid the chaos of Afghanistan’s post-Soviet civil war. The word “Taliban” means “students” – many early members were Afghan refugees or orphans educated in conservative Deobandi Sunni madrasas in Pakistan. **Mullah Mohammad Omar**, a cleric from Kandahar, organized a group of pious but battle-hardened Pashtun students to combat warlordism and instill order via strict **Sharia law**. The Taliban rapidly expanded, capturing Kandahar in late 1994, then Herat (1995), and eventually Kabul in September 1996. They declared the **Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan**, with Mullah Omar as “Amir al-Mu’minin” (Commander of the Faithful). The Taliban regime imposed an extreme interpretation of Islamic law – banning most female education and employment, enforcing beard length and dress codes, and carrying out harsh punishments. Their ideology is often described as **Deobandi fundamentalism mixed with Pashtun tribal customs**, distinct from al-Qaeda’s global jihadism (the Taliban’s focus was mostly internal: to establish an Islamic state in Afghanistan). By 2001, the Taliban controlled about 90% of Afghanistan’s territory, though their rule was recognized formally by only three countries (Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, UAE).

During their rule, the Taliban gave sanctuary to **Osama bin Laden and al-Qaeda**, who had relocated to Afghanistan in 1996. Despite requests, the Taliban refused to hand over Bin Laden after al-Qaeda’s 9/11 attacks, directly leading to the U.S.-led invasion in October 2001 that **toppled the Taliban regime**.

**Insurgency and Return to Power:** After 2001, the Taliban regrouped as an insurgency, with **Pakistan’s border areas** serving as rear bases. Over a 20-year guerrilla campaign, they sought to expel NATO and U.S. forces and overthrow the U.S.-backed Afghan government. The Taliban insurgency (led at times by Mullah Omar until his 2013 death, then by Mullah Akhtar Mansour, and later by Mullah Haibatullah Akhundzada) carried out relentless bombings, ambushes, and assassinations. By the late 2000s, the Taliban had shadow governors in many provinces and threatened much of Afghanistan’s rural areas, although they could not capture major cities while foreign troops remained. After the U.S. began negotiating with the Taliban, a peace deal was signed in February 2020 setting the stage for an American withdrawal. In August 2021, the **Taliban astoundingly swept back to power**, seizing Kabul as the U.S.-trained Afghan army melted away. They re-established the Islamic Emirate. Thus, the Taliban is unique among the groups discussed: it evolved from non-state militia to *de facto* state power (twice). The Taliban’s second regime (2021–present) once again imposed ultra-conservative Islamic rules (severely curtailing women’s rights and eliminating secular education for girls) and has faced international isolation and sanctions.

**Ideological Outlook:** The Taliban’s ideology is Sunni **Islamist and neo-fundamentalist**, rooted in the Deobandi school (influenced by Wahhabi-like austerity). It is *not* explicitly expansionist beyond Afghanistan, unlike al-Qaeda or ISIS. The Taliban have historically been **deeply anti-Shia** in practice – viewing the Shia minority (especially ethnic Hazaras) as heretical. This led to *massacres of Shia civilians* under Taliban rule, most infamously in 1998 in Mazar-i-Sharif, where Taliban fighters killed thousands of Hazaras and also **murdered 9 Iranian diplomats** and a journalist at the Iranian consulate【41†L137-L146】【41†L139-L148】. That incident brought **Iran and the Taliban to the brink of war** in 1998; Tehran massed troops on the border and only refrained from invading after UN mediation【41†L141-L149】. Thus, in the 1990s, **Iran considered the Taliban a hostile enemy** – a **Sunni extremist regime persecuting Shia** and allied to Pakistan (Iran’s rival) and hosting al-Qaeda. The deep antagonism was mutual: the Taliban denounced Iran’s Shia theocracy as un-Islamic, and clashes occurred along the Iran-Afghan border. For example, aside from the diplomat murders, the Taliban in 2000 razed Bamyan’s ancient Buddha statues (an act partly motivated by spite toward Shia Hazaras and done despite Iranian appeals).

**Links to Iran – Early Enmity and Later Pragmatism:** Given this history, one might assume **Iran and the Taliban would never collaborate**. Indeed, during the Taliban’s first regime (1996–2001), Iran actively **backed the anti-Taliban Northern Alliance**, providing arms and funding to Tajik and Hazara militias fighting the Pashtun-dominated Taliban. Iran nearly went to war with the Taliban in 1998 after the Mazar-i-Sharif killings【41†L139-L148】【41†L169-L177】. However, **after 2001**, geopolitical realities prompted a **shift**. The U.S. military presence in Afghanistan was a common enemy for both Iran and the ousted Taliban. **Iran quietly began to engage the Taliban insurgency** as a **hedge against the U.S.** and the influence of ISIS and other threats. By the mid-2000s, reports emerged (from NATO and Afghan officials) that **Iran was supplying the Taliban with weapons, training, and funding** in a limited but notable capacity【29†L115-L123】【42†L142-L150】. This was paradoxical – Iran was also cooperating with the new Afghan government it publicly supported – but Iran was playing a “**double game**,” as U.S. Defense Secretary Robert Gates put it【29†L119-L123】. General Stanley McChrystal’s 2009 report noted Iran was providing development aid to Afghanistan’s government *and* “allowing support to the Taliban” simultaneously【29†L115-L123】.

Evidence of **Iran’s covert aid to Taliban insurgents** includes: **interdicted shipments of Iranian-made arms** (such as explosively-formed penetrators, EFPs, and surface-to-air missiles) destined for the Taliban【29†L115-L123】; the presence of Taliban cadres in **Iranian territory**; and the activities of the IRGC’s elite Quds Force. For example, in 2007 British forces intercepted a convoy in Herat province carrying Iranian arms to the Taliban. In 2010, the U.S. Treasury designated two IRGC-Quds Force officers for arranging lethal aid (including roadside bombs) to Taliban commanders. According to declassified U.S. intelligence and Afghan officials, **Iran’s Quds Force established training camps for Taliban fighters on Iranian soil** (e.g. in Kerman and Zahedan), and **Taliban fighters received combat training from IRGC instructors** before re-entering Afghanistan【50†L59-L67】. Iranian agents also allegedly paid bounties for each U.S. soldier the Taliban killed (as per some Afghan intelligence reports in 2012). By providing such support, Iran pursued **multiple objectives**: eroding the U.S./NATO position next door, gaining leverage over the Taliban’s future behavior, and defending Iran’s own interests in western Afghanistan. Indeed, Iran cultivated especially strong ties with Taliban factions operating near Iran’s border (Herat/Farah provinces), even as it continued to oppose hardcore anti-Shia Taliban elements.

The **depth of Iran-Taliban ties** grew such that by the late 2010s, Russia and Iran were both informally aiding the Taliban as a counterweight to ISIS’s Afghan branch (ISIS-K) and in anticipation of an American withdrawal. In 2015, Afghan and Western officials confirmed that Iran had **Taliban leaders living in Mashhad** and occasionally supplying them with drones and night-vision equipment. Iran also hosted Taliban delegations for secret talks. This culminated after the Taliban’s return to power: in **February 2023, Iran formally handed the Afghan Embassy in Tehran to the Taliban’s appointed diplomats**, effectively recognizing the Taliban government to a degree【42†L124-L132】【42†L126-L134】. By then, **the enmity of the 1990s had morphed into pragmatic engagement**. Iran and the Taliban now coordinate on trade, border security, and water rights – albeit amid mutual distrust (border skirmishes still occur, e.g. a deadly clash over water in 2023). It’s a startling turnabout: the same Iran that nearly invaded Afghanistan to fight the Taliban now maintains cordial if uneasy ties with the Taliban regime.

However, Iran’s influence on the Taliban should not be overstated. The Taliban remain fundamentally Sunni fundamentalists with their own independent power base. Tensions persist, particularly over the Taliban’s treatment of Shia Hazaras (attacks on Hazara mosques by the Taliban or ISIS-K worry Tehran) and over shared water resources (the Helmand River dispute). Iran has pressed the Taliban to form an inclusive government and respect Shia minority rights, but with little success. In 2022–2023, firefights erupted on the Iran-Afghan border, showing the relationship is far from an alliance.

**State-Level Sponsorship and Accusations:** Despite the new Taliban-Iran modus vivendi, **Iran’s earlier support to the Taliban insurgency is well documented**. The U.S. and Afghan governments repeatedly accused Iran of arming the Taliban as a state sponsor of terrorism. For instance, a 2017 U.S. military report stated Iran’s **IRGC was “providing money, training, and weapons to the Taliban”**, including facilitating Taliban leaders’ sanctuary in Iran【50†L59-L67】. In 2020, the U.S. Treasury went further, naming an al-Qaeda operative in Iran as a link between Iran and Taliban’s Haqqani faction. Iran usually **denied these claims**, calling them “baseless propaganda.” Iranian officials admitted to “contacts” with the Taliban but said these were to protect Iran’s interests (like safeguarding Shiites and encouraging peace talks) rather than to aid attacks on Americans. Nonetheless, evidence such as the U.S. District Court judgment in *Cabrera vs. Iran* – which reviewed classified info and concluded Iran **“provided material support to the Taliban and al-Qaeda causing deaths of U.S. soldiers”** – underscores that Iran did play a covert role in the Taliban’s war against U.S./NATO forces【50†L75-L83】. According to that court, IRGC-Quds Force units (specifically the Ansar Corps based near Afghanistan) were instrumental in assisting Taliban insurgents【50†L59-L67】.

In sum, the **Iran–Taliban relationship has evolved from fierce hostility to cautious cooperation** over 25 years. During the Taliban’s first regime and the early U.S. occupation of Afghanistan, Iran’s stance was aggressively anti-Taliban. But as geopolitical winds changed, Iran shifted to a **“tactical alliance”** with elements of the Taliban – enough to bleed U.S. forces and ensure Iran wasn’t encircled by U.S. allies【50†L59-L67】. Now that the Taliban are in power again, Iran seeks a stable neighbor it can work with (better the Taliban, Tehran figures, than chaos or ISIS-K). Iran provides electricity and fuel to Afghanistan and engages the Taliban diplomatically【42†L142-L150】【42†L144-L153】. Yet deep suspicions remain – rooted in sectarian difference and historical bloodshed. The Taliban, for their part, balance their ties with Iran against their ties with Pakistan and Gulf states. They occasionally voice support for Iran against U.S./Israel (for example, **the Taliban condemned Israeli strikes on Iran in 2025**, an unusual public siding with Tehran【50†L21-L29】【50†L59-L67】). Such gestures signal a **marriage of convenience**: Iran and the Taliban will cooperate against common foes (like ISIS or Israel/U.S.) while carefully managing the ideological chasm between them【50†L53-L61】. Iranian state media now downplays past animosity and emphasizes Muslim unity, but neither side forgets the others’ true nature. Therefore, **Iran’s linkage to the Taliban can be characterized as indirect, covert support born out of realpolitik rather than genuine alignment**, with Iran at times a sponsor of Taliban militants, and now a begrudging neighbor trying to influence Taliban governance from the outside.

## Hamas
**Background and Formation:** **Hamas** (an acronym for *Harakat al-Muqawama al-Islamiyya*, or Islamic Resistance Movement) is a Palestinian Sunni Islamist organization operating primarily in the Gaza Strip and West Bank. While Hamas was founded in **December 1987** – slightly before the end of the Cold War – its evolution and prominence largely occurred in the post-Cold War period, making it a major group to consider. Hamas emerged at the start of the **First Intifada** (Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation) as an offshoot of the Muslim Brotherhood. Its founding leaders, notably **Sheikh Ahmed Yassin**, envisioned a movement that combined Palestinian nationalist goals with political Islam. Hamas’s 1988 charter called for the destruction of Israel and the establishment of an Islamic state in historic Palestine. The group quickly gained popularity through a network of da’wah (social/religious outreach) institutions – schools, charities, clinics – alongside its armed activities.

**Ideology and Structure:** Hamas is ideologically Sunni Islamist (Muslim Brotherhood lineage), emphasizing jihad against Israeli occupation. It fuses Palestinian nationalism with Islamist rhetoric, describing all of Palestine as an Islamic trust (waqf) that cannot be relinquished. Initially, Hamas’s stance toward Shia Iran was cautious due to sectarian and geopolitical differences (Iran was then closely allied with Yasser Arafat’s secular Fatah during the 1980s). Over time, Hamas pragmatically developed ties with any state willing to support the Palestinian cause, including Iran. Hamas has a political bureau (historically headquartered in exile in places like Damascus and Doha) and a military wing, the **Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades**. Key figures have included co-founders Ahmed Yassin and Abdel Aziz al-Rantisi (both assassinated by Israel in 2004), long-time political chief **Khaled Mashal**, and current Gaza leaders **Ismail Haniyeh** and **Yahya Sinwar**.

**Major Activities and Timeline:** Hamas became known in the 1990s for a campaign of **suicide bombings** inside Israel – especially during the Oslo peace process, which Hamas opposed. Notable attacks (1994–1997) targeted buses, cafes, and markets, killing scores of Israeli civilians. During the Second Intifada (2000–2005), Hamas carried out some of the deadliest bombings, solidifying its reputation as a leading resistance faction. In **2006**, Hamas surprised observers by winning the Palestinian legislative elections (defeating the Fatah party). This led to a brief unity government, then a violent rift: in June 2007, Hamas took control of **Gaza** by force, ousting Fatah officials. Since 2007, Hamas has governed the Gaza Strip, while the Palestinian Authority (under Fatah) administers parts of the West Bank. Under siege conditions in Gaza, Hamas and Israel have fought multiple **wars**: major escalations occurred in **2008-09 (Operation Cast Lead)**, **2012**, **2014 (50-day war)**, and beyond. Hamas’s tactics include firing rockets (often indiscriminately) into Israeli cities and digging cross-border tunnels for attacks or abductions (e.g., the 2006 capture of Israeli soldier Gilad Shalit). Israel’s military responses have caused heavy damage in Gaza. The cycle of conflict has been recurrent, with truces mediated by regional powers.

In **October 2023**, Hamas launched its most audacious operation: a surprise large-scale attack from Gaza into southern Israel (killing around 1,200 Israelis and taking >200 hostages). This unprecedented assault triggered a massive Israeli retaliation and a new Gaza war. Western and Israeli officials suggested such a complex operation likely involved **Iran’s hand**, which brings us to Hamas’s relationship with Iran.

**Linkages to Iran:** **Iran has been a major sponsor of Hamas for decades**, particularly after the mid-1990s and increasingly in the 2000s. This might seem counter-intuitive – Hamas is Sunni and was initially aligned with the Sunni Muslim Brotherhood, whereas Iran’s regime is Shiite and had historically supported Shia groups like Hezbollah. However, **Iran has embraced Sunni militants when it serves Iran’s anti-Israel and anti-U.S. agenda**. By the early 1990s, Iran saw the Palestinian cause as a way to gain pan-Islamic legitimacy and to bleed Israel. After 1991, as secular PLO leaders engaged in U.S.-brokered peace talks, Iran **forged relations with rejectionist groups**: Hamas and the smaller **Palestinian Islamic Jihad (PIJ)**. Iran provided these groups with financial aid, weapons, and training to bolster armed resistance against Israel【31†L41-L49】【31†L51-L58】.

Throughout the Second Intifada, Israeli intelligence reported that **Iran (via the IRGC-Quds Force and Hezbollah) was transferring funds and technical know-how to Hamas** for making bombs and longer-range rockets. A key turning point came after Hamas’s 2006 election victory: when much of the West cut off funding to Hamas, **Iran stepped in as a key financier**. Iran allegedly gave Hamas tens of millions of dollars annually. By 2008, Hamas leaders were openly visiting Tehran. Iranian-supplied **Fajr-5 artillery rockets** began appearing in Hamas’s arsenal – these longer-range rockets (smuggled via Sudan/Egypt or directly shipped to Gaza before Egypt’s crackdown) enabled Hamas to reach Tel Aviv and Jerusalem in the 2012 conflict. In a 2012 speech, Hamas’s Gaza prime minister Ismail Haniyeh thanked Iran for arms and funds that enabled Hamas to “hit the Tel Aviv occupation” with rockets.

However, there was a brief strain: the outbreak of the **Syrian Civil War in 2011** put Hamas in a tough spot between its Sunni identity and its Iranian patron. Hamas’s political bureau (then in Damascus) refused to back Assad’s brutal crackdown on mostly Sunni rebels, and in 2012 Hamas leaders left Syria, implicitly siding with the Syrian opposition. Iran, which was all-in for Assad, responded by temporarily cutting funding to Hamas (and instead boosting support to PIJ). For a few years, Hamas’s ties with Iran cooled. Nonetheless, by 2014–2015, Hamas-Iran relations warmed again due to their **shared hostility toward Israel** and perhaps mutual need (Hamas needed funds; Iran sought to unite its axis amid regional polarization). 

Since then, Iran has consistently been acknowledged as **Hamas’s chief military sponsor**. According to U.S. and Israeli officials, Iran provides an estimated **$100 million per year** split among Hamas and PIJ【31†L131-L139】. Iran has supplied **weapons technology** – for example, Iranian engineers taught Hamas to build improved rockets and drones domestically (using smuggled components and local workshops). Israeli military intelligence believes many of Hamas’s rockets are basically **Iranian designs** (the Qassam rockets evolved with Iranian input; the longer-range M-75 and Sejjil rockets are derived from Iran’s Fajr and M302 rockets). In addition, **Hamas fighters have routinely trained in Iran and with Hezbollah in Lebanon**. Dozens (if not hundreds) of Hamas operatives traveled to Iran or Syria for training in fields like rockets, drones, tunneling, and commando tactics【31†L139-L146】. A **Western intelligence official** disclosed that Hamas operatives trained in IRGC-run camps outside Gaza and then returned to impart skills to others【31†L69-L77】【31†L139-L147】. For instance, the use of paragliders by Hamas in the October 2023 assault was cited as a capability that **“surely required training outside of Gaza”** – likely in places like Iran or Lebanon【31†L103-L111】.

Iranian leaders have not hidden this relationship. **Iran’s supreme leader and IRGC commanders frequently praise Hamas**. Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi spoke with Hamas’s Haniyeh in 2023, calling the militant offensive a proud achievement. After the Oct 2023 Hamas attack, the White House’s Deputy NSC Advisor stated: “Iran is broadly complicit… They have provided them [Hamas] weapons, training, and financial support for decades”【31†L113-L121】. Iranian officials have publicly mentioned supporting the “Palestinian resistance” to the tune of hundreds of millions of dollars. Hamas leader Haniyeh in 2022 thanked Iran for $70 million in military aid that year【31†L131-L139】.

Iran provided Hamas with **components for guided munitions** and assisted in developing drones and anti-tank missiles. Iran’s smuggling network through Sudan/Sinai was largely disrupted by 2014 (with multiple Israeli airstrikes on convoys), so Iran shifted to teaching Hamas to build weapons indigenously using common materials (fertilizer for explosives, fiberglass pipe for rocket bodies, etc.). Still, Iranian-made weapons occasionally show up; in 2021, Hamas deployed an unmanned submersible drone, likely with Iranian input.  
- *Training:* The IRGC’s Quds Force and **Hezbollah (Iran’s Lebanese proxy)** have trained Hamas cadres. Some training occurred in **Lebanon’s Bekaa Valley** under Hezbollah supervision【31†L139-L146】, some in **IRGC camps in Iran** (possibly in Khuzestan desert or near Qom). Training areas cover tactics like urban warfare, sniper techniques, and use of advanced weapons (like UAVs). The close relationship between Hamas’ armed wing and Hezbollah is evidenced by Hezbollah’s openly coordination with Hamas during conflicts, and shared tactics (e.g., both dug extensive tunnel networks, likely exchanging expertise).  
- *Ideological and diplomatic support:* Iran portrays Hamas as part of the “Axis of Resistance” against Israel. It provides Hamas leaders with diplomatic cover and media platforms (Iran’s state media gives Hamas ample positive coverage). 

While Iran is a predominantly Shia state, it frames the Palestinian issue in pan-Islamic terms, thus justifying backing a Sunni group. Hamas, for its part, downplays sectarian differences when it comes to Iran. A senior Hamas official once stated: *“Iran’s support is unconditional and purely out of Islamic solidarity.”* Though that may gloss over Iran’s strategic interests, it reflects Hamas’s acceptance of aid regardless of sect. 

**State-Level Sponsorship and Reactions:** Israel has long accused Iran of **“outsourcing” terrorism to proxies like Hamas**. The U.S. Treasury has sanctioned numerous individuals and companies in Iran, Lebanon, and elsewhere for financing Hamas (e.g., an IRGC-QF operative, **Fawzi Shahada**, was sanctioned for coordinating Iranian money transfers to Hamas and PIJ). Sunni Arab governments, historically distrustful of Iran, also acknowledge Iran’s role. For example, Saudi Arabia and Egypt often criticized Hamas’s ties to Iran (particularly when it destabilized Gaza or linked to conflicts like Yemen). After the 2023 Hamas-Israel war, Western officials openly credited Iranian support for dramatically improving Hamas’s military capabilities (such as more precise rockets and military-grade drones seen in 2023)【31†L77-L86】【31†L139-L147】. 

At the same time, **Iran officially denies direct control** of Hamas operations. After the Oct 7, 2023 attack, Iran’s UN mission claimed: *“We are not involved in Palestine’s response, as it is taken solely by Palestine itself”*【31†L119-L127】. Iranian leaders insist Hamas makes its own decisions, even as they cheer the results. This plausible deniability is typical – Iran provides the means, but Hamas chooses the timing and tactics. Israeli and U.S. intelligence in 2023 said they had *no evidence of Iran issuing the specific order* for the Oct 7 attack【31†L61-L69】. Nonetheless, IRGC officials had reportedly helped Hamas with planning and training for complex operations over the preceding year【31†L41-L49】. The consensus in investigative journalism (e.g. **Washington Post** reporting) is that **Iran was deeply involved in Hamas’s force buildup**, making it *“broadly complicit”* in Hamas’s ability to wage war【31†L13-L21】【31†L41-L49】.

**Hezbollah as a Conduit:** Iran often uses Hezbollah to interface with Hamas. Hezbollah acts as a mentor and quartermaster for Palestinian militants under Iran’s guidance. For example, when relations were strained due to Syria, Hezbollah continued some level of cooperation with Hamas. Many Hamas operatives evacuated from Damascus in 2012 found refuge in Hezbollah’s Beirut stronghold (Dahiya), at least temporarily. Hezbollah helped broker restored Iran-Hamas ties by 2017. In summary, **Hamas’s link to Iran is substantial and direct**: **financial sponsorship, arms supplies, and military training** are the pillars of the partnership【31†L113-L121】【31†L131-L139】. This is a classic case of **state-level sponsorship of a non-state actor**. Iran’s motivation is to pressure Israel and gain leverage in the region by supporting Palestinian armed struggle, while Hamas benefits from the resources of a regional power to augment its guerrilla and terrorist capabilities. Other governments (from the U.S. and EU to Arab states) have officially designated Hamas as a terrorist organization and frequently single out Iran for enabling Hamas. Israeli officials often say Iran “has the blood of our citizens on its hands” via Hamas and PIJ rockets. On the other side, Hamas leaders credit Iran for their military successes – a Hamas official in 2021 stated openly: *“All the weapons we use to fight Israel, we got thanks to Iran”*. 

There is an ironic footnote: Hamas remains ideologically Sunni and has at times repressed Gaza’s tiny Shia community (some Gazans who converted to Shiism under Iranian influence have faced persecution by Hamas). But these sectarian issues are minor compared to the strategic alignment against Israel. As a **result, Iran, Hamas, PIJ, and Hezbollah** now form a coordinated axis. Iranian media calls Hamas “the Palestinian branch of the Islamic Revolution.” And Hamas’s recent operations have borne hallmarks of Iranian tactical input (e.g., use of drones to disable Israeli border sensors in 2023, which is an IRGC-style innovation). 

To conclude, **Iran’s relationship with Hamas is one of patron and client, forged for the purpose of confronting Israel**. It stands as a prominent example of Iran extending its revolutionary influence beyond the Shia sphere to a Sunni militant group – underscoring that Iran’s support for “terrorist organizations with Middle Eastern roots” extends across sectarian lines when convenient. Iranian officials half-jokingly refer to Hamas (and PIJ) as “Sunni Hezbollah,” emphasizing that for Tehran, the **cause of “resistance” transcends sect** when it comes to fighting Israel. The longevity and increasing depth of Iran-Hamas ties, despite ups and downs, demonstrate the strategic value both sides derive from this partnership.

*(Sources: Washington Post investigative report【31†L41-L49】【31†L51-L58】; statements by U.S. NSC officials【31†L113-L121】; State Dept 2020 report【31†L131-L139】; Council on Foreign Relations; Reuters and BBC monitoring of Iran-Hamas relations.)*

---

**Conclusion:** In the decades since the Cold War, the Greater Middle East has seen the rise of numerous militant organizations – each with its own local origins and goals, yet many entangled in the region’s broader geopolitical rivalries. A recurring theme in the above profiles is the role of the Islamic Republic of **Iran** as an influencer – sometimes adversary, sometimes patron – of these groups:

- Iran directly **created and controls Hezbollah**, a Shia militia that is effectively an arm of Iranian policy【21†L328-L336】【21†L331-L338】. 
- Iran cultivated ties with **Sunni groups like Hamas and Palestinian Islamic Jihad**, providing them significant support against Israel【31†L131-L139】【31†L139-L146】. 
- Iran has a convoluted love-hate history with **al-Qaeda** – fighting its offshoots in some theaters while clandestinely harboring or assisting elements of it to hurt U.S. interests【11†L158-L162】【15†L49-L57】.
- Iran fiercely opposed **ISIS** and contributed to its defeat, underscoring sectarian divides (Shia Iran vs. ISIS’s anti-Shia jihad) rather than any collusion.
- Iran’s relationship with **the Taliban** flipped from near-war in 1998 to tactical cooperation against the U.S., to a wary neighborly relationship today【50†L59-L67】【42†L142-L150】.
- Meanwhile, purely local Sunni extremist movements like **Boko Haram** have remained outside Iran’s sphere, aligning instead with Iran’s Sunni jihadist rivals (al-Qaeda/ISIS), and thus received no Iranian patronage – indeed Boko Haram stands ideologically antithetical to Iran’s revolutionary Shiism.

**State-level sponsorship** has been a key factor in the endurance and potency of many of these groups. Iran features prominently as *the* state sponsor for Hezbollah, Hamas, PIJ, and certain Iraqi and Yemeni militias, leveraging them as proxies to project power. Other states have also been accused of sponsorship: for example, some Gulf Arab states’ citizens funneled funds to al-Qaeda, and Pakistan’s security services long supported the Taliban. But Iran’s role, given its revolutionary ideology and its IRGC’s mandate, is unique in scope and consistency. The **Iranian government officially denies supporting “terrorist” groups**, framing its assistance as support for “liberation movements” or denying involvement altogether (as seen in its denials regarding al-Qaeda presence and Hamas operations)【31†L119-L127】【15†L11-L19】. However, evidence from **intelligence agencies, the United Nations, trials, and even admissions by group leaders** paints a detailed picture of Iran’s extensive network of partnerships.

In evaluating each group’s ties to Iran, it’s clear that **ideology is not always a barrier** to cooperation – pragmatic common cause can trump sectarian divides. Iran’s supreme leader Ali Khamenei once dubbed the U.S., Israel, and Sunni jihadists like ISIS as “Takfiri enemies,” while praising Sunni Hamas as “heroic resistance.” This illustrates Iran’s selective approach. On the receiving end, groups like Hamas and the Taliban have shown that hardline Sunnis can accept aid from a Shia power if it serves their objectives.

Finally, these linkages have had significant geopolitical implications. They have fueled proxy wars (e.g., Iran vs Saudi via support of different factions in Yemen, Syria, etc.), complicated counterterrorism efforts (Iran’s harboring of al-Qaeda figures created an intelligence blind spot and a diplomatic dilemma), and entrenched conflicts (Iran’s support helps sustain Hezbollah’s conflict with Israel indefinitely, and empowers Hamas in ways that periodically lead to war). They have also led to Iran’s increased isolation: Iran remains designated by the U.S. as the world’s **“leading state sponsor of terrorism,”** largely due to the very connections discussed above. Understanding these origins and linkages – through primary sources, government findings, academic analyses, and investigative journalism – is essential for any comprehensive security assessment of the Middle East’s post-Cold War landscape.
